scoreBands.label: Low Risk
scoreBands.blurb: Great job! You have excellent habits that minimize face bloat. Keep up the good work!

scoreBands.label: Mild Risk
scoreBands.blurb: You're doing well overall, but there are a few areas where small changes could make a big difference.

scoreBands.label: Moderate Risk
scoreBands.blurb: Several factors are contributing to facial puffiness. The good news? These are all manageable with the right approach.

scoreBands.label: High Risk
scoreBands.blurb: Multiple factors are likely causing significant facial bloating. Let's create a comprehensive plan to address these issues.

questions.text: How would you describe your sleep quality over the past week?

options.title: Excellent - 8+ hours, deep sleep, wake refreshed
options.context: Perfect! Quality sleep is your secret weapon against facial puffiness. Your cortisol levels stay balanced and fluid retention minimized.

options.title: Good - 7-8 hours, mostly restful
options.context: Great sleep habits! Minor improvements in consistency could give you even better results.

options.title: Fair - 6-7 hours, some restless nights
options.context: Consider establishing a bedtime routine and aiming for 7.5-8 hours to reduce morning puffiness.

options.title: Poor - 5-6 hours, frequently interrupted
options.context: Sleep debt significantly impacts facial fluid retention. Prioritizing sleep will show results within days.

options.title: Very poor - less than 5 hours most nights
options.context: Severe sleep deprivation is a major driver of facial bloating. This should be your #1 priority to address.

options.title: Irregular - wildly varying sleep schedule
options.context: Sleep schedule inconsistency disrupts your circadian rhythm and stress hormones. Stabilizing your bedtime is crucial.

options.title: Chronic insomnia - difficulty falling/staying asleep
options.context: Chronic sleep issues require a comprehensive approach. Consider sleep hygiene changes and potentially professional support.

options.title: Sleep disorders - diagnosed sleep apnea or similar
options.context: Sleep disorders directly impact facial swelling. Work with your healthcare provider while implementing complementary strategies.

questions.text: How much water do you typically drink per day?

options.title: 2.5+ liters, evenly spaced throughout day
options.context: Excellent hydration strategy! Consistent water intake helps your body release excess sodium and reduces puffiness.

options.title: 2-2.5 liters, mostly consistent
options.context: Good hydration! Try spacing intake more evenly and consider electrolyte balance for optimal results.

options.title: 1.5-2 liters, somewhat irregular
options.context: Increase to 2+ liters and focus on consistency. Your kidneys will better regulate fluid balance.

options.title: 1-1.5 liters, often forget to drink
options.context: Mild dehydration signals your body to retain water, causing puffiness. Set hourly reminders to sip water.

options.title: Less than 1 liter, rely on other beverages
options.context: Significant dehydration is likely contributing to facial bloating. Pure water should be your primary beverage.

options.title: Minimal water, mostly coffee/sodas
options.context: Caffeine and sugar worsen dehydration. Replace half your drinks with water for immediate improvement.

options.title: Drink when thirsty only
options.context: Thirst indicates you're already dehydrated. Proactive hydration is key to reducing facial puffiness.

options.title: Often go entire days with minimal fluids
options.context: Severe dehydration forces your body into conservation mode, causing significant facial swelling. Start with small, frequent sips.

questions.text: How often do you eat high-sodium foods (processed foods, restaurant meals, chips, etc.)?

options.title: Rarely - cook fresh, whole foods daily
options.context: Perfect! Low sodium intake prevents excess fluid retention. Your face benefits from this clean eating approach.

options.title: Occasionally - 1-2 times per week
options.context: Great balance! When you do indulge, drink extra water and consider potassium-rich foods the next day.

options.title: Moderately - 3-4 times per week
options.context: Try reducing by one meal per week and add potassium-rich foods (bananas, spinach) to balance sodium.

options.title: Frequently - 5-6 times per week
options.context: High sodium intake is likely a major contributor to facial puffiness. Focus on home cooking for faster results.

options.title: Daily - at least one high-sodium meal/snack
options.context: Daily sodium spikes cause persistent facial bloating. Start by replacing one processed meal with fresh ingredients.

options.title: Multiple times daily - processed foods dominate
options.context: Excessive sodium is overwhelming your kidneys' ability to regulate fluid. Gradual reduction will show quick face changes.

options.title: Almost exclusively - convenience/fast foods
options.context: Ultra-processed foods contain sodium levels that guarantee facial puffiness. Even small fresh food additions help.

options.title: Extreme - add extra salt to already salty foods
options.context: Sodium overconsumption is creating chronic facial swelling. Professional nutrition guidance may be beneficial alongside gradual changes.
